Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Assessing adaptative capacity in response to climate change: terrestrial salamanders in an urban heat island mesocosm
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will provide insights into the capacity of species to adapt to fragmented and warming habitats, and so inform actions that will be most effective in conserving biodiversity under climate change. Faced with changing climate, organisms either adapt in place or move to track conditions that they are adapted to. In the absence of these responses, they may go locally extinct. Relative to movement, adaptation in response to environmental change remains poorly understood in wild populations. Fortunately the recent development of genetic techniques for detecting adaptation in nature has made it easier to evaluate this response. Collaborations established under this project include educational outreach through the Duke Forest Office, North Carolina Central University, and the Scientific Research and Education Network.

This project will study the capacity of a terrestrial salamander (Plethodon cinereus) to respond to local variability in temperature via adaptation. In the Piedmont of North Carolina, local heat islands resulting from development provide habitats that are substantially warmer than natural forests. This history of development has resulted in local warming over timescales ranging from <10 to >100 years, providing a quasi-experimental gradient in exposure time to elevated temperatures. Genetic variation within and among salamander populations will be assessed at a genome-wide scale using reduced representation, next-generation genomic sequencing methods. In combination with environmental covariates, novel genotype-environment outlier detection analyses will be used to partition genomic data into neutral and potentially adaptive variation; these data sets allow for the measurement of gene flow within and between populations and local adaptation, respectively. Integration of these data uses a Bayesian approach for modeling the covariance in neutral or adaptive allele frequencies as functions of geographic and environmental distances. Gene flow is assessed via covariance of neutral genetic markers on graph-theoretic estimates of geographic separation; local adaptation is measured in terms of covariance of genetic markers under selection on environmental dissimilarity. Relative effect sizes will identify instances of dispersal subsidy or isolation of better-adapted genotypes, as represented by locations where landscape configuration or the pace of development interferes with the ability of the resident salamanders to track local climate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In May 2017, with the support of an NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant, Brenna Forester successfully completed her dissertation, “Using landscape genomics to conserve adaptive capacity: a case study with a Southern Appalachian salamander.” Forester is an ecologist interested in how species can adapt to human-mediated changes in the environment. Because of fragmented habitats and dispersal limitations, many species may not be able to move to track environmental change. For these species, the ability to adapt to changing conditions in place may be a critical response to prevent local extirpation or extinction. While studies of evolutionary adaptation were once limited to model organisms such as fruit flies, recent technical advances have made these studies possible in any species. Forester and other researchers are still developing best practices for this type of research, especially in species for which there is no prior genetic information.

During her funding period, Forester focused on testing new statistical methods in the field of landscape genomics, which investigates the effects of landscape and environmental characteristics on genetic variation. She applied these new methods to understand the effects of urbanization on a climate sensitive species, the eastern red-backed salamander (Plethodon cinereus). Preliminary results indicate that urban salamander populations are subject to different climatic conditions compared to their rural counterparts, including increased temperatures during their active season. Most of these urban salamanders show reduced levels of adaptive genetic variation and reduced population size when compared with rural salamander populations, while all populations are subject to increased genetic differentiation due to habitat fragmentation. One urban salamander population that retained high levels of adaptive genetic variation was distinguished by a relatively large population size. These results indicate that isolation has a negative effect on the adaptive capacity of urban salamanders that are subject to changing environmental conditions, except in cases where population numbers remain high. Reconnecting urban salamander habitats to restore gene flow would be an effective approach to mitigate these losses of genetic biodiversity. Alternatively, assisted migration could be used to supplement genetic diversity.

During her funding period, Forester worked with the Scientific Research and Education Network, creating a high school lesson plan on climate change and species distributions that allows students to build, interpret, and evaluate models using real data to address conservation issues. She also worked with the Duke Forest Office to produce educational signage about her NSF-funded research for a local nature trail, which passes through one of the salamander populations used in the study. Forester also worked with North Carolina state wildlife managers to evaluate a salamander species of state concern using the methods and analytical framework developed during this NSF-funded research. Now that Forester has completed her dissertation, she is continuing to work on understanding the adaptive capacity of species in the face of environmental change, collaborating with conservation professionals to more effectively integrate that research into applications that will improve management outcomes and better protect biodiversity, from genes to ecosystems.
